newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS- US December T-bond options expire quietly.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS- US December T-bond options expire quietly.

text.p: Implied volatilities for U.S. debt options were flat to softer just before noon on Friday and December T-bond options were poised to expire quietly at noon, dealers said.

"We've got the usual frustration with expiration in that there's pretty much an equally distributed open interest in the 114-00, 115-00 and 116-00 calls," said Brad Tyl, senior vice president at Aubrey G Lanston.
As a result, the expiration was having little effect on the underlying futures markets, he said.
"It's just not dramatic," he said.

The only expiration-related excitement stemmed from a rumor, in the morning, that a large options player held 10,000 December 115-00 calls. Traders who were short the calls were concerned the player would take profits above that level, which may have had some effect on the market, Tyl said.
Another options dealer said open interest in the December 115-00 call was slightly higher than other strikes, at 25,000.

As a result, he belived it unlikely the underlying futures market would close above that level. "I don't expect the market to settle above 115-00 even...that's about the excitement so far this expiration day," he said.

At 1145 CST/1745 GMT, implied volatility for January serial T-bond options was flat at 9.4 percent. Implied volatility for March T-bond options was down 0.15 percentage point at 9.75 percent, dealers said.
One large investment house was said to have bought 1000 March 110-00 puts and sold the same number of March 120-00 calls.
"That was the biggest bearish trade I've seen coming into the option pit," one trader said.
Another house sold 3000 March 114-00/116-00 call spreads, which helped depress implied volatility, he said.
Implied volatility for March eurodollar options was also flat at 10.5 percent, said one dealer speaking from Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
After a brisk morning, December T-bond futures appeared to have stalled near 115-00 and March euros were stuck near 94.50, he said.
"We're stuck in a range right now. That's how you've got to play it out," he said.
He said one investment house sold 2000 June 94.50 calls.
Tyl said trade in T-bond options indicates the underlying futures market may be topping out.
The put-to-call ratio for T-bond options, which had been showing a two-to-one bias for calls, has begun to narrow with fewer calls in demand, he said.
"It's weaning...meaning the market is running out of steam," he said.
-Danielle Bochove (312)408-8750
E-mail:derivatives@reuters.com
